principles.name: Team Collaboration as Third Pillar
principles.description: 'If I think about my best hires... there's some sort of either, collaborator or team, you know, teamwork, approach that's embedded in the personality, you know, not a loaner.' This adds to critical thinking and business acumen as core hiring criteria.

principles.name: Linear Answers as Guardedness Signal
principles.description: 'What I'm listening for is if it's like every answer is very linear, it just comes across as guarded. So I end up trusting them less because now they're just telling me what I want to hear.' Overly polished responses indicate inauthentic communication.

principles.name: Nonverbal Cue Baseline Assessment
principles.description: Standard awareness of 'nonverbal cues of whether they're nervous or whether they're looking away when they answer, or fidgety' but these are less important than communication style assessment.

patterns.name: Authenticity Detection Through Response Style
patterns.description: Evaluate response authenticity by listening for overly linear, guarded answers that suggest the person is telling you what they think you want to hear.
patterns.context: Interview situations where candidates may be coached to give perfect answers rather than authentic responses that reveal their actual thinking.

patterns.name: Three-Pillar Hiring Framework
patterns.description: Assess candidates on critical thinking, business acumen, and collaborative/teamwork personality as core requirements for hiring decisions.
patterns.context: Hiring processes where both analytical capability and interpersonal effectiveness are crucial for role success.

examples.name: Third Pillar - Team Collaboration
examples.content: When asked what he might add to critical thinking and business acumen as hiring pillars, Dan identifies team collaboration: 'if I think about my best hires... there's some sort of either, collaborator or team, you know, teamwork, approach that's embedded in the personality, you know, not a loaner.'

examples.name: Detecting Guardedness Through Linear Responses
examples.content: Beyond standard nonverbal cues, Dan listens for 'if it's like every answer is very linear, it just comes across as guarded. So I end up trusting them less because now they're just telling me what I want to hear.' This overly polished response style signals inauthentic communication.
